page.title: 10Staploe, Agriculture
page.content: Four relatively large landowners, who run their farming operations from Upper Honeydon, Goodwick, The Falls (Staploe) and Basmead (Staploe) work 1100, 1430, 750 and 1000 acres respectively. Typically "North Bedfordshire clay" farmers with approximately 80% of their land in cereals, they use potatoes, brussel sprouts, field peas and beans as break-crops. Farmers at Field Farm, Two Brewers, Coxfield, Cottage Farm and Bushmead Farm grow similar crops on a smaller scale. All are owner occupiers. Some sugar beet, onions and cauliflowers are grown and a small acreage of land is under grass, let for sheep grazing and cattle. The farm at Coxfield owns and grazes 80 cattle. There is a 120-sow pig-unit at Tythe Farm. There is still a relatively high labour force for harvesting vegetables
